node.text:
Mountains are memorable, but chances are good that if you’ve visited Glacier, you’ve enjoyed some of the gorgeous grasslands on the park’s east side. You may have stopped at one to photograph wildflowers or watch a grizzly bear. A good example is in St. Mary, which you can view on this webcam. 

Prior to the establishment of the park, Native Americans followed bison across these grasslands, using traditional ecological knowledge to maintain a highly diverse and intact biome. Over the past century, the park’s grasslands have been impacted by settlement, livestock grazing, park and concessioner development, noxious weed invasion, and change in fire regimes. 

In 1999, park ecologists established 155 permanent vegetation monitoring plots in 99 different meadows. 

For this week’s Science Friday, we had the chance to go out with the botany crew. They’re spending the summer surveying those plots established 20 years ago to evaluate how the vegetation has changed. What changes do you think you might see? 

#sciencefriday #glaciernationalpark #parkscience #botany #wildflowers #ecology #climatechange

node.title: Science Friday - The Grasslands, They Are A-Changin'

node.text:
This video will help you prepare for using the recreation.gov mobile site to purchase a Going-to-the-Sun Road ticket. Tickets are limited and can sell out before you get one even if you are prepared, but knowing how to use the site puts you in the best position to successfully acquire one.

To learn more about ticketed entry visit our website, https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/gtsrticketedentry.htm.

node.title: How To Get a $2 Going-to-the-Sun Road

node.text: On Science Friday this week, we learn all about the loon banding project happening here in Northwest Montana. We then get to go out--at night--to bring you a firsthand look at what it takes to capture and band loons! #ScienceFriday #ParkScience #wildlifebio

node.text:
Glacier National Park is classified as a Class 1 airshed under the Clean Air Act. This designation affords the highest level of air quality protection provided under the Act. 

Fresh air, dramatic views, and pristine water are some of the qualities that draw visitors to Glacier from all over the world. Air quality in the park affects obvious things, like visibility. It also has less obvious impacts - on water quality, forest composition and ecosystem function. 

Glacier has had a permanent air quality monitoring site since 1980. The site includes devices and networks that measure different components of the atmosphere. 

Join us for this Science Friday, as the park's Physical Scientist shows us around the site and explains how we measure air quality in Glacier! 

#ScienceFriday #ScienceInParks #GlacierNationalPark #ParkScience #AirQuality

node.title: Science Friday- What's in the Air?

node.text:
You probably expect that Glacier protects things like bears and rivers. Did you know, though, that the park also protects and preserves over 700 historic structures?

Welcome back to Season Two of Science Fridays with Ranger Melissa! We are so excited to continue exploring, learning, and discovering science and research in the park with you! 
This week, we learn about historic buildings in Glacier from the park's historical architect, Kim Hyatt.

node.title: Science Friday - Historic Buildings of Glacier

node.text:
Have you missed us? Science Friday with Ranger Melissa is back with a great final Science Friday video for you! This week, Melissa goes out with John Waller, the park’s bear biologist, to explore the trail for signs of bears, discover differences between bears in Glacier and elsewhere, and learn about how bears live at different times of year. 

#ParkScience #ScienceFriday #Bears #Hibernation #GlacierNationalPark #WildlifeBiology #ScienceInParks

node.title: Science Friday - Glacier's Bears with John Waller

node.text: This week, we are bringing you a VERY special Science Friday. Ranger Melissa travels to an active archaeological site on the east side of the park to meet with archaeologist Brent Rowley. A river has been eroding away the bank, revealing some incredible things about the history of this place. Watch more to find out what they discover! #sciencefriday #parkscience #archaeology #scienceinparks #glaciernationalpark

node.title: Science Friday - Archaeological discovery with Brent Rowley

node.text: Learning about the special connection Native Peoples have to Glacier National Park can expand the way you think about this place. Visit the park’s official website to see more videos like this.

node.title: The Park is a Living Creature

node.accessibility_caption: A brown-furred snowshoe hare sitting on the forest floor.

node.text:
If animals had a fashion show, who would win best dressed? 💃🕺

One contestant would be the snowshoe hare, one of the few mammals in Montana that changes the color of its outfit to suit the season.

Can you spot the snowshoe hare in both of these photos? A brown summer coat helps hares to blend in with their surroundings. In the fall, they turn white to prepare for winter. The main goal of this camouflage? To not be eaten! 

There's a long list of critters that would love to have hare for lunch—Canada lynx, bobcats, mountain lions, wolves, coyotes—and blending in is incredibly effective at helping you conserve energy while not being eaten. If you naturally blend in with your environment, you can spend a lot less energy looking for predators or places to hide. 

Can you think of any other critters whose outfit balances form with function?

node.accessibility_caption: A brown-furred snowshoe hare sitting on the forest floor.
A brown snowshoe hare blending in with woody vegetation.
Photo by Glacier National Park on August 08, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Millions of visitors from across the world travel to Glacier National Park for its amazing scenery and wildlife each year. Yes, millions! You’ve likely heard about how busy the park has become recently, but how do these high visitation rates impact your trip? 

Several places in the park fill up with cars every morning during the summer months. The earliest parking lots to fill are Logan Pass and Avalanche Creek. Areas with limited vehicle carrying capacity, like Two Medicine, Many Glacier, and Bowman and Kintla Lakes, also fill to overflowing most mornings, leading rangers to restrict inbound traffic at these entrances during the middle part of the day to avoid unsafe gridlock situations. 

The park maintains a website, the Recreation Access Display (RAD), that reflects current campground and parking capacities: https://www.nps.gov/applications/glac/dashboard/ 
It allows you to see which campgrounds and parking areas are full and what time they filled the previous day, as well as which areas are restricting traffic due to congestion. 

There is also a park shuttle service to help visitors avoid the frustration that results from such vehicle overcrowding and congestion. Reservations for shuttle tickets can be made on the recreation.gov website: https://www.recreation.gov/ticket/facility/10087424. 

Visitors simply interested in driving, sightseeing, or short hikes, as opposed to longer hikes that take most of the day, may find the park to be less congested in the late afternoon and evening hours. 

Image description: a ground squirrel on a rock above a busy parking lot.

node.accessibility_caption: Cars queue up in front of a brown campground kiosk.

node.text:
What to know before you go: Glacier's Campgrounds 

Camping in Glacier provides visitors with unforgettable memories and unrivaled access to the park. 

There are plenty of opportunities to camp while you're here—multiple campgrounds, hundreds of sites—but they are all in high demand! A successful trip requires planning and setting expectations. 

Fish Creek Campground is reservation-only. Campers without reservations may occasionally find walk-up availability, but to find a site you must check with the ranger at the campground kiosk. Even sites without tags may be reserved. Reservations for Fish Creek can be made up to six months in advance on Recreation.gov.

Many Glacier Campground is also reservation-only. Unlike Fish Creek though, there is no walk-up availability. Many Glacier campsite can only be booked on Recreation.gov. 

Apgar Campground is first-come, first-served. Each morning, would-be campers line up on foot just outside the campground entrance as park staff work to identify available sites. At 8 am, staff let the waiting line of visitors into the campground to secure campsites of their own! You’ll need a Going-to-the-Sun Road ticket to enter Apgar and look for a first-come, first-served campsite between 6 am and 5 pm.

Campsites at Fish Creek or Apgar Campgrounds act as a valid entry ticket for Glacier's Going-to-the-Sun Road Ticketed Entry system. If you're staying at Apgar though, be sure to check with the campground host to get a slip showing proof of camping for re-entry.
Happy camping!

For information on all of Glacier's campgrounds visit: https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/camping.htm.

node.text:
Mountains are memorable, but chances are good that if you’ve visited Glacier, you’ve enjoyed some of the gorgeous grasslands on the park’s east side. You may have stopped at one to photograph wildflowers or watch a grizzly bear. A good example is in St. Mary, which you can view on this webcam. 

Prior to the establishment of the park, Native Americans followed bison across these grasslands, using traditional ecological knowledge to maintain a highly diverse and intact biome. Over the past century, the park’s grasslands have been impacted by settlement, livestock grazing, park and concessioner development, noxious weed invasion, and change in fire regimes. 

In 1999, park ecologists established 155 permanent vegetation monitoring plots in 99 different meadows. 

For this week’s Science Friday, we had the chance to go out with the botany crew. They’re spending the summer surveying those plots established 20 years ago to evaluate how the vegetation has changed. What changes do you think you might see? 

#sciencefriday #glaciernationalpark #parkscience #botany #wildflowers #ecology #climatechange

node.accessibility_caption: A group of people ride in a Cadillac car with a mountain slope in the background.

node.text:
"Today, for the first time in my life, I have seen Glacier Park. Perhaps I can best express to you my thrill and delight by saying that I wish every American, old and young, could have been with me today. The great mountains, the glaciers, the lakes and the trees make me long to stay here for all the rest of the summer." - President Franklin D. Roosevelt

87 years ago today, on August 5, 1934, Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt had a whirlwind visit to Glacier as part of a tour of the West that summer. After arriving in West Glacier in the morning via private train car, their party rode over the newly constructed Going-to-the-Sun Road in special red Cadillacs that were built in the 1920s for transporting VIPs in the park. The party made stops at Logan Pass and Civilian Conservation Corps Camp #11 in St. Mary before heading up to the Many Glacier Hotel for lunch. 

They then went south to Two Medicine, where a CCC chorus sang several songs and a group of Blackfeet performed traditional dances. The Blackfeet inducted both Franklin and Eleanor into the tribe and gave them the names “Lone Chief” and “Medicine Pipe Woman.”

That evening, from the Two Medicine Chalets, FDR delivered one of his fireside chats to the nation over the radio. The First Family then headed to East Glacier, where they met their train to head to their next stop, the Fort Peck Dam.

In this photo, taken near Logan Pass, FDR sits in the rear of the car on the passenger side, looking away from the camera. The Garden Wall and Bishop’s Cap can be seen in the background. #throwbackthursday #tbt

node.accessibility_caption: Water cascading over rock with a mountain view behind.

node.text:
If you’re planning to visit the Going-to-the-Sun Road this weekend, we’ve got exciting news for you!

Additional Going-to-the-Sun Road entry reservation tickets will be released on August 6, 7, and 8 at 11:00 am MDT. Unlike with other Going-to-the-Sun Road ticket sales, these batches of tickets released at 11:00am will be good starting the very same day they are purchased. The tickets are good for seven days and are only available from recreation.gov.

For more information about ticketed entry visit: https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/gtsrticketedentry.htm

What are you most excited to do with your Going-to-the-Sun Road entry reservation ticket?

node.accessibility_caption: A creek runs along a road with forest, snow-capped mountains, and blue sky in the background.

node.text:
One year ago today, the #GreatAmericanOutdoorsAct (GAOA) was signed into law. With $17.1 million of funding provided through GAOA, the park is rehabilitating a 9.3 mile portion of the Going-to-the-Sun Road from the foot of Lake McDonald to the intersection with the North Lake McDonald Road. The project will improve access and help repair features of the famous roadway.

#LWCF, #GreatAmericanOutdoorsAct

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on August 03, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and nature.

node.text:
We’re in the heart of peak season in Glacier, so be ready to share your experience here with plenty of new friends!

Respecting other visitors by sharing the trail, avoiding loud music and yelling near others, and being kind and courteous on the roads will help everyone have an enjoyable and memorable trip. 

What’s your best tip for recreating responsibly and respectfully?

[Image description: Crowds of visitors take photos on the Hidden Lake trail.]

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on August 02, 2021. May be an image of body of water and nature.

node.text:
This month the National Park Service will be celebrating the anniversary of the Great American Outdoors Act on August 4 and the 105th birthday of the National Park Service on August 25. Fees for Park Passes will be waived on both days.

Ticketed Entry will remain in effect for the Going-to-the-Sun Road. Reservations are required for the Going-to-the-Sun Road between 6 am and 5 pm. All other locations in the park do not require reservations. 

For information on reservation requirements visit our website at https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/gtsrticketedentry.htm

[image description] The cruise boat Sinopah carries passengers to trailheads at the head of Two Medicine Lake. The shoulder of towering Mt. Sinopah rises on the right and Lone Walker Mountain punctuates the skyline in the distance. 

#glaciernps #twomedicinelake #sinopah #boatcruise #feefreedays

node.accessibility_caption: A waterfall in a mossy landscape

node.text:
What do waterfalls have in common with parfaits? They have layers!

We've all gawked at a waterfall or two—they're impressive, beautiful, and dramatic—but how do they form?

Rushing water is powerful, scouring rock as it goes and moving it downstream. Before arriving at a waterfall, water flows over different rock layers, some of which are better at resisting erosion than others. 

In many cases, waterfalls form when rushing water transitions from flowing on a hard rock surface to a soft(er) rock surface.

Cascading water will erode the soft, low layer below much faster than the hard layer above. What may have once been a slight slope will slowly weather away to create a steep drop!

 As seen in the second picture, the waterfall begins on the hard rock surface (highlighted in red) of the upper stream bed. The softer rock surface (highlighted in blue) beneath has since been worn away by years of rushing water.

The tallest waterfalls in Glacier have a different origin, as they flow into valleys carved by ice-age glaciers. Altogether, the park is home to several hundred year-round and intermittent waterfalls—do you have a favorite?

Image descriptions: A waterfall on a mossy landscape, and the same waterfall with text and color highlighting the hard and soft rock layers in the falls.

node.text:
Which essential items do you always take on your hikes? 

With all but the highest elevation trails now snow-free, Glacier’s hiking season is in full swing! Over 700 miles of trails provide outstanding opportunities for everything from short walks to day hikes to extended backpacking trips into the backcountry. 

Hikers should be aware that there is no cell phone reception in most of the park. This means that little mistakes or injuries can sometimes become big emergencies for those not prepared. To stay safe, hike in a group when possible, leave a detailed itinerary with someone you trust, and check the park website for current trail status and conditions before you set out. Additionally, here is a packing list of some of the basics: 

✅Sturdy footwear 
✅Plenty of water 
✅Bear spray 
✅Rain gear/layers for warmth 
✅Lunch/snacks 
✅Sunscreen/hat 
✅Bug repellent 
✅First aid kit 

Of course, this list is not comprehensive, but having these items is a good start to enjoying a safe, scenic hike in Glacier National Park. What is on your hiking must-have list?

node.text:
Some say that there are two seasons in Montana: winter and construction. While visiting Glacier this year, you may experience delays due to road construction.

Returning visitors to Many Glacier Valley may recall the rough road and its many bumps and potholes. Underneath its surface, soil slides and slumps have occurred as the earth beneath the road has crept downslope, particularly when saturated. Soil movement increased after the construction of Sherburne Dam (1914-1921), and when Many Glacier Road was constructed (1927-1928), three slides started to form immediately. The frequent patches and repairs since then have added more pavement material, increasing the weight of the road, causing greater amounts of soil movement. The road crews’ project there this year has aimed for a long-term solution to these issues by both increasing soil water drainage underneath the road and fully rebuilding the road surface. Because of this, the road accessing Many Glacier remains under construction, and delays of 40 minutes can be expected from Babb to the end of Many Glacier Road. Longer delays (up to 3 hours) should be expected to enter or exit this area between 10 pm and 5 am.

On the west side of the park, major construction on Camas Road has now begun, which includes the building of a new entry station. If visitors are planning on traveling from Polebridge to the Apgar area, they should expect delays of about 20 minutes during the day. A portion of Camas Road is closed to all traffic (hiking, biking, and vehicles) from 7 pm to 6 am each night for the next three weeks. This four-mile stretch is between the turnoff to Fish Creek and just south of the Huckleberry Fire Lookout Trail. To see current conditions on all of the road construction projects occurring in and around the park, please see our website: https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/2021projectwork.htm.
